action.action-desc: Ms. Slaughter introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services

form.official-title: To amend the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 to prohibit Members of Congress from receiving a discounted price in certain private offerings of securities.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the End Congressional Stock Market Abuse Act of 2017.

section.header: Participation in securities transactions by public officials
section.text: Section 21A of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (15 U.S.C. 78u–1) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (i), by striking (within the meaning given such term in section 12(f)(1)(G)(i)) and inserting on a United States or foreign securities exchange; and
by adding at the end the following:

subsection.header: Participation in securities transactions by Members of Congress

clause.text: means any security that is regularly traded on a United States or foreign securities exchange; and
includes any comparable economic interest acquired through synthetic means such as the use of a derivative or short selling any publicly traded security;

subclause.text: in the case of a purchase, the national best offer, as defined in section 242.600(c) of title 17, Code of Federal Regulations;
in the case of a sale, the national best bid, as defined in section 242.600(c) of title 17, Code of Federal Regulations; or
any other value, as determined by the Commission; and

clause.text: does not include any commission or fee paid to a broker or third party; and

subparagraph.text: the term United States or foreign securities exchange means—

clause.text: a national exchange described in section 6; and
a designated offshore securities market, as defined in section 230.92 of title 17, Code of Federal Regulations.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (B), a Member of Congress may not—

clause.text: purchase a covered security for less than the price available on a United States or foreign exchange;
sell a covered security for more than the price available on a United States or foreign exchange; or
purchase a private placement offering of a covered security available on a United States or foreign exchange.

subparagraph.text: Subparagraph (A) shall not apply if a Member of Congress reasonably believes that—

clause.text: in the case of a purchase of a covered security, the discount was obtained in a manner generally available to the public; or
in the case of a sale of a covered security, the premium was obtained in a manner generally available to the public.
